{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|(163132) 2002 CU|11}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|(163132) 2002 CU|11}} | discovery_ref = | discoverer = [[Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research|LINEAR]] | discovered = 7 February 2002 | mpc_name = {{mp|(163132) 2002 CU|11}} | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous asteroid|PHA]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]  | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | aphelion = {{Convert|1.5795|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} | perihelion = {{Convert|0.85959|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | semimajor = {{Convert|1.2196|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | eccentricity = 0.29517 | period = 1.35 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (491.94 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 48.782° | asc_node = 157.77° | mean_anomaly = 47.609[[Degree (angle)|°]] | arg_peri = 110.54° | mean_diameter = {{val|0.460|0.017}} km
{{val|0.730}} km | mass = 5.3{{e|11}} kg (assumed) | albedo = {{val|0.408|0.061}} | magnitude = | abs_magnitude = 18.5 | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.73180|sup=ms}} / day (n) | observation_arc = 4600 days (12.59 yr) | uncertainty = 0 | moid = {{Convert|0.00189035|AU|km|abbr=on}} }} '''{{mp|(163132) 2002 CU|11}}''', provisional designation {{mp|2002 CU|11}}, is a bright, sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] of the [[Apollo asteroid|Apollo group]]. == Description == {{mp|2002 CU|11}} was discovered on 7 February 2002 by [[Lincoln Near-Earth Asteroid Research]] (LINEAR) at an [[apparent magnitude]] of 19 using a {{convert|1.0|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[reflecting telescope]]. It has an estimated diameter of {{convert|730|m|sp=us}}. The asteroid was listed on [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]] with a [[Torino Scale]] rating of 1 on 20 March 2002. With an observation arc of 44 days, {{mp|(163132) 2002 CU|11}} showed a 1 in 9,300 chance of [[Impact event|impacting]] Earth in 2049. It was removed from the Sentry Risk Table on 26 April 2002. It is now known that on 3 September 2049 the asteroid will be {{convert|0.0843|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. Even though using an [[Epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] of 27 June 2015 gives {{mp|2002 CU|11}} an Earth-[[Minimum orbit intersection distance|MOID]] of {{convert|0.0000093|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}}, the asteroid does not make any threatening approaches to Earth in the foreseeable future. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" |+Notable close-approaches to Earth |- ! Date !! Distance from Earth |- | 1925-08-30 || {{convert|0.0023|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} |- | 2014-08-30 || {{convert|0.0346|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} |- | 2049-09-03 || {{convert|0.0843|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} |- | 2080-08-31 || {{convert|0.0042|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=off}} |} {{Large_near_earth_asteroid_flybys 2LD}} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type=2010-08-11 last obs and revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A multi-decadal oceanographic programme that undertakes biological, chemical and physical research during annual voyages between the UK and destinations in the South Atlantic" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A multi-decadal oceanographic programme that undertakes biological, chemical and physical research during annual voyages between the UK and destinations in the South Atlantic}} The '''Atlantic Meridional Transect''' (abbreviated as '''AMT''') is a multi-decadal [[oceanography|oceanographic]] programme that undertakes biological, chemical and physical research during annual voyages between the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and destinations in the South Atlantic. The ongoing AMT programme was begun in 1995 to assess biological processes in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] from the [[Eddy (fluid_dynamics)#Mesoscale ocean eddies|mesoscale]] through to [[oceanic basin|basin]]-scale. An early activity of the programme was the [[calibration]] of measurements and products produced by the [[SeaWiFS]] (1997-2010) satellite-based sensor for ocean [[chlorophyll]].
The AMT programme is led by [[Plymouth Marine Laboratory]], with support from the [[National Oceanography Centre]]. It is currently funded by the [[Natural Environment Research Council]] (NERC). Since its inception in 1995, the programme has undertaken 26 research cruises with 256 scientists drawn from 22 countries.<ref name="aboutAMT">{{cite web |url=http://www.amt-uk.org/About-AMT |title=About AMT |date=2017 |website= |publisher= |access-date=November 16, 2017 |quote=Since 1995 ... [this] has involved a total of 26 research cruises with 256 scientists from 22 countries}}</ref> The AMT programme has provided data for more than 300 [[scientific publication|refereed publications]],<ref name="pubsAMT">{{cite web |url=http://www.amt-uk.org/Publications |title=Publications |date=2017 |website= |publisher= |access-date=November 16, 2017 |quote=To date the AMT programme has produced over 300 refereed journal articles, including three special issues of journals}}</ref> as well as 75 [[PhD thesis|PhD theses]].<ref name="aboutAMT"/>
The return cruise track of the AMT programme operates between the UK in the North Atlantic and the [[Falkland Islands]], [[Chile]] or [[South Africa]] in the southern hemisphere, and its total distance can be up to {{convert|13000|km|mi}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.amt-uk.org/Cruises |title=Cruises |date=2017 |website= |publisher= |access-date=November 16, 2017 |quote=... the annual return passage of research ships ... [is] a distance of up to 13,500km}}</ref> The track crosses a number of [[biogeochemistry|biogeochemical]] provinces, including [[Primary production#Oceanic production|productive]] [[temperate climate|temperate]] and [[Upwelling#Equatorial|equatorial upwelling]] systems, and the [[Oligotroph#Ocean|oligotrophic]] northern and southern Atlantic [[ocean gyre]]s. In sampling this diverse range of [[plankton]]ic [[ecosystem]]s, the cruises of the AMT programme provide a consistent dataset over a broad spatial scale, and play an important role in understanding the oceanic [[carbon cycle]].
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.amt-uk.org/Home AMT homepage] * [https://oceancolor.gsfc.nasa.gov/SeaWiFS/ SeaWiFS project homepage]
[[Category:Biological oceanography]] [[Category:Climate change]] [[Category:Oceanography]]

{{cleanup|date=April 2010}} {{Lead rewrite|date=February 2016}} {| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Boulder Climate Action Plan Fund (Colorado)''' |- ! Locale: | [[Boulder, CO]] |- ! Established: | April 1, 2007 |- ! Incentive Type: | Public Benefits Fund |- ! Applicable Sector: | Commercial, Industrial, Residential |} The '''Climate Action Plan (CAP) ''' is a set of strategies intended to guide community efforts for reducing [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. Those strategies have focused on improving energy efficiency and conservation in our homes and businesses—the source of nearly three-fourths of local emissions. The plan also promotes strategies to [[Emissions reduction#Reduction efforts|reduce emissions]] from transportation, which account for over 20 percent of our local greenhouse gas sources. ==General information== In November 2006, citizens of [[Boulder, Colorado]], voted to approve Ballot Issue No. 202, authorizing the city council to levy and collect an [[excise tax]] from residential, commercial and industrial electricity customers for the purpose of funding a climate action plan(1)City of Boulder R.S. 3–12, accessed 2010-02-02 http://www.colocode.com/boulder2/chapter3-12.htm to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The plan outlines programs to increase energy efficiency, increase renewable energy use, reduce emissions from motor vehicles, and take other steps toward the goal of meeting the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. Beginning April 1, 2007 and expiring March 31, 2013, the initial tax rate was set at $0.0022/kWh for residential customers, $0.0004/kWh for commercial customers, and $0.0002/kWh for industrial customers. The city council has the authority to increase the tax after the first year up to a maximum permitted tax rate of $0.0049/kWh for residential customers; $0.0009/kWh for commercial customers; and $0.0003/kWh for industrial customers. Voluntary purchases of utility-provided [[wind power]] are exempt from the tax. ==Allocation and generation of fund== '''Charge''':
Current tax rates for electricity customers (link to 7): {| class="wikitable" |- ! Electricity User Type ! Tax Rate ! Average Annual Tax |- | Residential | $0.0049/kWh | $21 |- | Commercial | $0.0009/kWh | $94 |- | Industrial | $0.0003/kWh | $9,600 |} '''Total Fund:'''$860,265 in the first year and up to $1,342,000/year thereafter through 3/31/2013
'''Purpose:''' Renewable energy, energy efficiency, transportation
https://web.archive.org/web/20110227063524/http://www.bouldercolorado.gov/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=7698&Itemid=2844 ==Incentive authority== '''Authority 1:''' Ballot Issue 202 (Climate Action Plan Tax)
Date Enacted:11/7/2006
https://web.archive.org/web/20110718220332/http://www.bouldercolorado.gov/files/Elections/2006/climate_action_plan_ord.pdf '''Authority 2:''' Boulder Revised Code 3-12
Date Effective: 4/1/2007
Expiration Date: 3/31/2013
http://www.colocode.com/boulder2/chapter3-12.htm ==See also== *[[Carbon pricing]] *[[Global Action Plan]] *[[Transition Towns]] *[[Greenhouse gas emissions by the United States]] *[[Chicago Climate Action Plan]] *[[San Francisco Climate Action Plan]] *[[Biodiversity Action Plan]] *[[Obama’s Climate Action Plan]] ==References== *DSIRE Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency accessed 2010-02-02 [http://www.dsireusa.org/][http://www.baaqmd.gov Bay Area Air Quality Management District] *[http://www.sparetheair.org Spare the Air website] *[http://www.chemicalprocessing.com/articles/2006/128.html?page=print Managing TitleV Compliance] *[http://www.cleanair.com/Reference/Library/library.html Clean air reference website] *[http://www.contracostatimes.com/search/ci_8086302?IADID=Search-www.contracostatimes.com-www.contracostatimes.com&nclick_check=1 Fireplace Rebate Fund] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080930143535/http://sparetheair.org/contact.htm BAAQMD phone numbers] including 800-EXHAUST (800-394-2878) to report smoggy cars {{Reflist}} [[Category:Air pollution]] [[Category:Emissions reduction]] [[Category:Action plans]]

{{Infobox book | name = British Soldierflies and Their Allies | image = Soldierflies.gif | alt = Cover | caption = The cover of the first edition | author = Alan E. Stubbs, Martin Drake | illustrator = David Wilson | country = [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] | language = [[English language|English]] | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[British Entomological and Natural History Society]] | pub_date = 2001 | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]]) | pages = 528 | isbn = 978-1899935048 }} '''''British Soldierflies and their allies (an illustrated guide to their identification and ecology)''''' is a book by [[Alan E. Stubbs]] and [[Martin Drake]], published by the [[British Entomological and Natural History Society]] in 2001.<ref name="nhbs2001">{{cite web|title=British Soldierflies and their Allies|url=https://www.nhbs.com/british-soldierflies-and-their-allies-book-2|website=www.nhbs.com|date=Dec 2001|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref> A second edition was published in 2014.<ref name="nhbs2014">{{cite web|title=British Soldierflies and their Allies|url=https://www.nhbs.com/british-soldierflies-and-their-allies-book|website=www.nhbs.com|date=Oct 2014|accessdate=27 March 2018}}</ref>
It is a sequel to an earlier volume, ''[[British Hoverflies: an identification guide]]''<ref name="nhbs2001"/>, and covers the following families of [[true fly|flies]], which collectively are known as the "[[Larger Brachycera]]": [[Acroceridae]], [[Asilidae]], [[Athericidae]], [[Bombyliidae]], [[Rhagionidae]], [[Scenopinidae]], [[Stratiomyidae]], [[Tabanidae]], [[Therevidae]], [[Xylomyidae]] and [[Xylophagidae]].
The book introduced [[English names for organisms|English names]] for all included species, the first time this has been done in a scientific reference work for a whole group of flies.
It contains a set of photographic plates by [[David Wilson (photographer)|David Wilson]].
==See also== * [[List of soldierflies and allies recorded in Britain]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.benhs.org.uk/publications/british-soldierflies-and-their-allies-second-edition/ British Soldierflies and Their Allies (2nd Edition)] British Entomological & Natural History Society website
{{DEFAULTSORT:British Soldierflies And Their Allies}} [[Category:Entomological literature]]

{{For|other comets discovered by Terry Lovejoy|Comet Lovejoy (disambiguation){{!}}Comet Lovejoy}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox Comet | name=C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy) | image=Comet Lovejoy Near the Big Dipper.png | caption=C/2013 R1 on 28 November 2013, three-minute exposure using a 6" [[refractor]] | discoverer=[[Terry Lovejoy]]
(Thornlands, Qld., Australia) | discovery_date=7 September 2013 | epoch=14 December 2013 | perihelion=0.8118 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] (q) | aphelion=~800 AU (epoch 2050) | eccentricity=0.9984 | period=~6,300 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] ([[Epoch (astronomy)|epoch]] 1950)
~7,600 yr (epoch 2050) | inclination=64.04° | last_p=22 December 2013 }} '''C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy)''' is a long-period [[comet]] discovered on 7 September 2013 by [[Terry Lovejoy]] using a {{convert|0.2|m|in|0|adj=on|sp=us}} [[Schmidt–Cassegrain telescope]]. It is the fourth comet discovered by Terry Lovejoy. C/2013 R1 crossed the [[celestial equator]] on 14 October 2013, becoming a better [[Northern Hemisphere]] object. ==History== By 1 November 2013, the comet was visible to the [[naked eye]] near the [[Beehive Cluster]] (M44), about halfway between [[Jupiter]] and [[Regulus]]. It became more impressive than [[comet ISON]]. In binoculars, the comet has the appearance of a green, unresolved [[globular cluster]]. C/2013 R1 made its closest approach to Earth on 19 November 2013 at a distance of {{convert|0.3967|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}}, and reached an [[apparent magnitude]] of about 4.5. On 27 November 2013 the comet was in the constellation of [[Canes Venatici]], near the bottom of the handle of the [[Big Dipper]]. From 28 November until 4 December 2013, the comet was in the constellation [[Boötes]]. On 1 December 2013 it passed the star [[Beta Boötis]]. From 4 December until 12 December 2013, the comet was in the constellation [[Corona Borealis]]. From 12 December until 14 January 2014, the comet was in the constellation [[Hercules (constellation)|Hercules]]. On 14 December 2013, it passed the star [[Zeta Herculis]]. The comet came to [[Apsis|perihelion]] (closest approach to the Sun) on 22 December 2013 at a distance of {{convert|0.81|AU|km mi|abbr=on}} from the Sun. At perihelion, the comet had an [[Elongation (astronomy)|elongation]] of 51 degrees from the Sun. By September 2014, the comet had fainted to magnitude 18. == References == {{reflist | refs = {{cite web |date=9 September 2013 |title=MPEC 2013-R72 : COMET C/2013 R1 (LOVEJOY) |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K13/K13R72.html |accessdate=10 November 2013}} (CK13R010) {{cite web |date=9 November 2013 |title=MPEC 2013-V48: Observations and Orbits of Comets |publisher=IAU Minor Planet Center |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K13/K13V48.html |accessdate=10 November 2013}} {{cite web |publisher=[[Gary W. Kronk]]'s Cometography |title=C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy) |url=http://cometography.com/lcomets/2013R1.html |accessdate=10 November 2013}} {{cite web |date=8 November 2013 |title=The Other Great Morning Comet |publisher=[[Sky & Telescope]] |author=Tony Flanders |url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/observing/highlights/The-Other-Great-Morning-Comet-231157211.html |accessdate=10 November 2013}} {{cite web |date=8 November 2013 |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2013R1;cad=1#cad |accessdate=10 November 2013}} {{cite web |date=9 November 2013 |title=C/2013 R1 ( Lovejoy ) |publisher=Seiichi Yoshida's Comet Catalog |author=Seiichi Yoshida |url=http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/2013R1/2013R1.html |accessdate=10 November 2013}} {{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=2013R1 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy) |accessdate=10 November 2013}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]] and [[Barycentric coordinates (astronomy)|barycentric coordinates]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) {{cite web |url=http://astrobob.areavoices.com/2013/11/29/move-over-ison-time-to-share-the-love-with-comet-lovejoy/ |title=Move over ISON, time to share the love with Comet Lovejoy |work=Astro Bob |publisher=Areavoices.com |first=Bob |last=King |date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=29 November 2013}} {{cite web |date=2014-09-07 |title=MPEC 2014-R69 : Observations and Orbits of Comets |publisher=IAU Minor Planet Center |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K14/K14R69.html |accessdate=2014-09-20}} }} == External links == {{commons category-inline|C/2013 R1}} *[http://scully.cfa.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/returnprepeph.cgi?d=c&o=CK13R010 Elements and Ephemeris for C/2013 R1 (Lovejoy)] – [[Minor Planet Center]] *[http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap131209.html Comet Lovejoy Over a Windmill] ([[APOD]] : 9 December 2013) {{Comets}} {{2013 in space}} {{2014 in space}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lovejoy, 2013 R1}} [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2013|20130907]] [[Category:Discoveries by Terry Lovejoy|2013R01]] [[Category:Comets in 2013|20131222]] [[Category:Comets in 2014|201401]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2013|20131119]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}}
[[Elephant]]s have been depicted in mythology, symbolism and popular culture. They are both revered in religion and respected for their [[war elephant|prowess in war]]. They also have negative connotations such as being a symbol for an unnecessary burden. Ever since the [[stone age]], when elephants were represented by ancient [[petroglyphs]] and [[cave art]], they have been portrayed in various forms of art, including pictures, sculptures, music, film, and even architecture.
[[File:Demetrius I of Bactria.jpg|right|200px|thumb|Elephant scalp worn by [[Demetrius I of Bactria|Demetrius I]] of [[Bactria]] (205–171 BC), founder of the [[Indo-Greek Kingdom]], as a symbol of his conquest. <small>-[[British Museum|British Museum]], Dept. of Coins & Medals<ref>Plate 39 (23), ''[https://archive.org/details/guidetoprincipal00brituoft A guide to the principal gold and silver coins of the ancients, from circ. B.C. 700 to A.D. 1 (1889)]''; British Museum. Dept. of Coins and Medals : "AR. Demetrius"</ref></small>]]
==Religion, mythology and philosophy== [[File:Ganesha Basohli miniature circa 1730 Dubost p73.jpg|200px|right|thumb|[[Ganesha]], [[Basohli]] miniature, ca. 1730, [[National Museum, New Delhi]]{{efn|''Ganesha Getting Ready to Throw His Lotus''  :  "In the Mudgalapurāṇa (VII, 70), in order to kill the demon of egotism (Mamāsura) who had attacked him, Gaṇeśa Vighnarāja throws his lotus at him. Unable to bear the fragrance of the divine flower, the demon surrenders to Gaṇeśa."}}]]
[[File:Elephant. Mold of Seal, Indus valley civilization.JPG|thumb|right|200px| Elephant seal from [[Indus Valley Civilization]] 2500–1500 BC]] The [[Asian elephant]] appears in various [[Asian religions|religious traditions]] and mythologies. They are treated positively and are sometimes revered as deities, often symbolising strength and wisdom. Similarly, the [[African elephant]] is seen as the wise chief who impartially settles disputes among the forest creatures in African fables,<ref name="Natures-Ways(2006)">{{cite book|title=Nature's Ways Lore, Legend, Fact and Fiction.|year=2006|publisher=F+W Media|location=Newton Abbot|isbn=9780715333938|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U6jRwf2eY6kC&lpg=PP1&pg=PT70#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=6 December 2012|chapter=Animal Ways}}</ref> and the [[Ashanti people|Ashanti]] [[African traditional religion|tradition]] holds that they are human chiefs from the past.<ref name="A-gallery">{{cite web|title=Elephant|url=http://www.a-gallery.de/docs/mythology.htm|work=Myths, legends, beliefs and traditional stories from Africa|publisher=A-gallery|accessdate=6 December 2012}}</ref>
The Earth is supported and guarded by mythical [[World Elephant]]s at the compass points of the [[cardinal directions]], according to the [[Hindu cosmology]] of [[ancient India]]. The classical [[Sanskrit literature]] also attributes earthquakes to the shaking of their bodies when they tire. Wisdom is represented by the elephant in the form of the deity [[Ganesh]], one of the most popular gods in the [[Hindu religion]]'s [[Hindu pantheon|pantheon]]. Sometimes known as Ganesha, this deity is very distinctive in having a human form with the head of an elephant. This was put on after the human head was either was cut off or burned, depending on the version of the story from various Hindu sources. Lord Ganesha's birthday (rebirth) is celebrated as the Hindu festival known as [[Ganesha Chaturthi]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Festivals : Ganesh Chaturthi|url=http://www.swaminarayan.org/festivals/ganeshchaturthi/index.htm|publisher=[[Bochasanwasi Shri Akshar Purushottam Swaminarayan Sanstha]]|accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref> In [[Japanese Buddhism]], their adaptation of Ganesha is known as [[Kangiten]] ("Deva of Bliss"), often represented as an elephant-headed male and female pair shown in a standing embrace to represent [[unity of opposites#Coincidentia oppositorum|unity of opposites]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sanford|first1=James H.|editor1-last=Brown|editor1-first=Robert L.|title=Ganesh : studies of an Asian god|date=1991|publisher=State University of New York Press|location=Albany|isbn=0791406563|page=289|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oF-Hqih3pBAC&lpg=PA307&pg=PA289|chapter=Literary Aspects of Japan's Dual-Gaņeśa Cult}}</ref>
In [[Hindu iconography]], many ''[[Deva (Hinduism)|deva]]s'' are associated with a mount or vehicle known as a ''[[vāhana]]''. In addition to providing a means of transport, they symbolically represent a divine attribute. The elephant ''vāhana'' represents wisdom, divine knowledge and royal power; it is associated with [[Lakshmi]], [[Brihaspati]], [[Shachi]] and [[Indra]]. [[Indra]] was said to ride on a flying [[White elephant (animal)|white elephant]] named [[Airavata]], who was made the King of all elephants by Lord Indra. A white elephant is rare and given special significance. It is often considered sacred and symbolises royalty in Thailand and Burma, where it is also considered a symbol of good luck. In Buddhist iconography, the elephant is associated with [[Queen Māyā of Sakya]], the mother of [[Gautama Buddha]]. She had a vivid dream foretelling her pregnancy in which a white elephant featured prominently.<ref name=BuddhaNet>{{cite web|title=Life of Buddha (part 1) : Queen Maha Maya's Dream|url=http://www.buddhanet.net/e-learning/buddhism/lifebuddha/1lbud.htm|website=BuddhaNet|publisher=Buddha Dharma Education Association}}</ref> To the royal sages, the white elephant signifies royal majesty and authority; they interpreted the dream as meaning that her child was destined for greatness as a universal monarch or a ''buddha''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=ed|first1=Kevin Trainor, general|title=Buddhism : the illustrated guide|date=2004|publisher=Oxford Univ. Press|location=New York|isbn=0195173988|pages=24–25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_PrloTKuAjwC&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Elephants remain an integral part of religion in South Asia and some are even featured in various religious practices.<ref name=Clarke>{{cite book|last=Clarke|first=Jacqueline L. Schneider ; foreword by Ronald V.|title=Sold into extinction : the global trade in endangered species|publisher=Praeger|location=Santa Barbara, California|isbn=0313359393|pages=104}}</ref> [[Temple elephants]] are specially trained captive elephants that are lavishly [[caparison]]ed and used in various temple activities. Among the most famous of the temple elephants is [[Guruvayur Keshavan]] of [[Kerala, India]]. They are also used in festivals in [[Sri Lanka]] such as the [[Esala Perahera]].
In the version of the [[Chinese zodiac]] used in [[Northern Thailand]], the last year in the 12-year cycle – called "Year of the [[Pig (zodiac)|Pig]]" in China – is known instead as "Year of the Elephant", reflecting the importance of elephants in Thai culture.
[[File:IRHT 126277-p-detail.jpg|left|thumb|150px|[[Eleazar Maccabeus]] illustration, ''[[Speculum Humanae Salvationis]]'']] In Islamic tradition, the year 570 is when the Prophet [[Muhammad]] was born and is known as the [[Year of the Elephant]].<ref name=Watt>{{cite book|last1=Watt|first1=W. Montgomery|title=Muhammad : prophet and statesman|date=1977|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=London|isbn=0198810784|page=7|edition=[Repr]}}</ref> In that year, [[Abraha]], ruler of [[Yemen]] tried to conquer [[Mecca]] and demolish the [[Kaaba]], reportedly in retaliation for the previous Meccan defilement of [[Al–Qalis Church, Sana'a|Al–Qalis Church]] in [[Sana'a]], a cathedral Abraha had constructed.<ref name="Hajjah">Hajjah Adil, Amina, "''Prophet Muhammad''", ISCA, 1 Jun 2002, {{ISBN|1-930409-11-7}}</ref> However, his plan was foiled when his white elephant named Mahmud refused to cross the boundary of Mecca. The elephant, who led Abraha's forty thousand men, could not be persuaded with reason or even with violence, which was regarded as a crucial omen by Abraha's soldiers. This is generally related in the five [[Ayah|verses]] of the [[Sura|chapter]] titled '[[Al-Fil|The Elephant]]'{{efn|[[Sura]] 105: ''[[Al-Fil]]'' ({{lang-ar|سورة الفيل}} — {{lang-en|The Elephant}})}} in the [[Quran]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mir|first=Mustansir|title=Elephants, Birds of Prey, and Heaps of Pebbles: Farāhī's Interpretation of Sūrat al-Fīl|journal=Journal of Qur'anic Studies|year=2005|volume=7|issue=1|pages=33–47|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/25728163?uid=2&uid=4&sid=21102582220031|doi=10.3366/jqs.2005.7.1.33}}</ref>
In the [[Judeo-Christian]] tradition, [[medieval art]]ists depicted the mutual killing of both [[Eleazar]] the [[Maccabee]] and a [[war elephant]] carrying an important [[Seleucid]] general as described in the [[apocrypha]]l book of [[1 Maccabees]]. The early illustrators knew little of the elephant and their portrayals are highly inaccurate.<ref>{{cite web|title=Medieval Bestiary : Elephant|url=http://bestiary.ca/beasts/beast77.htm|publisher=Medieval Bestiary|accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref>
The unfamiliarity with the exotic beast has also made elephants a subject of widely different interpretations thus giving rise to mythological creatures. The story of the [[blind men and an elephant]] was written to show how reality may be viewed from differing perspectives. The source of this [[parable]] is unknown, but it appears to have originated in India. It has been attributed to [[Buddhism|Buddhists]], [[Hinduism|Hindus]], [[Jainism|Jainists]], and [[Sufism|Sufis]], and was also used by [[Discordianism|Discordians]]. The scattered skulls of prehistoric [[dwarf elephant]]s, on the islands of [[Crete]] and [[Sicily]] may have formed the basis of belief in existence of [[cyclops|cyclopes]],{{efn|The plural of cyclops is cyclopes ("sigh-KLO-peez")<ref name="AMNH-Giants"/>}} the one-eyed [[giant (mythology)|giants]] featured in [[Homer]]'s [[Odyssey]] (c. 800~600 BC). As early as the 1370s, scholars had noted that the skulls feature a large [[nasal cavity]] at the front that could be mistaken for a singular eye socket;<ref name="AMNH-Giants">{{cite web|title=Greek Giants|url=http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/past-exhibitions/mythic-creatures/land-creatures-of-the-earth/greek-giants|publisher=American Museum of Natural History|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref> and the skulls, twice the size of a human's, looked as if they could belong to giant humanoids.<ref name="AMNH-Giants"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Greek and Roman Mythology.|year=2007|publisher=MobileReference.com|location=Boston|isbn=9781605010915|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TkTOgNrm7noC&pg=PT329&dq=cyclops+pygmy+elephant&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xrbGUI-aKImQiQer2YCQBA&redir_esc=y|chapter=Cyclops}}</ref> It is also suggested that the [[Behemoth]] described in the [[Book of Job]] may be the elephant due to its grazing habits and preference to rivers.<ref>{{cite book|last=Slifkin|first=Natan|title=Sacred monsters : mysterious and mythical creatures of Scripture, Talmud and Midrash|year=2007|publisher=Zoo Torah|location=Brooklyn, N.Y.|isbn=1933143185|pages=183|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_1fdxxS26RYC&pg=PA183&dq=behemoth+elephant&hl=en&sa=X&ei=oLjGUJj1CO-diAeH6ICwAw&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=behemoth%20elephant&f=false|chapter=Behold the Behemoth}}</ref> {{clear|left}}<!-- Allow room for image -->
==In Art==
From Stone age [[rock-art]] to Modern age [[Street art|street-art]], the elephant has remained a popular subject for artists.
===Prehistoric=== [[Prehistoric North Africa]]ns depicted the elephant in [[Paleolithic age]] rock art. For example, the Libyan [[Tadrart Acacus]], a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage site]], features a rock carving of an elephant from the last phase of the [[Pleistocene epoch]] (12,000–8000 BC)<ref name=UNESCO>{{cite web|title=Rock-Art Sites of Tadrart Acacus|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/287|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=11 December 2012}}</ref> rendered with remarkable realism.<ref name=ScienceDaily(2012)Dec5>{{cite web |title=Were Cavemen Better at Drawing Animals Than Modern Artists? |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/12/121205200049.htm |publisher=Science Daily|accessdate=11 December 2012|date=5 Dec 2012 |quote=Source: reprinted from materials provided by [[Public Library of Science]]. }}</ref> There are many other prehistoric examples, including [[Neolithic]] [[rock art of south Oran (Algeria)]], and a white elephant rock painting in 'Phillip's Cave' by the [[San bushmen|San]] in the [[Erongo Region|Erongo]] region of [[Namibia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Phillip's Cave|url=http://www.info-namibia.com/en/activities-and-places-of-interest/erongo-outjo/phillipps-cave|publisher=Info Namibia|accessdate=16 March 2013}}</ref> From the Bovidian{{efn |During the African pastoral 'Bovidian period', there were many depictions of [[Bovid]] herds, suggesting the development of animal domestication<ref>{{cite book |last=etc|first=edited by Thurstan Shaw, |title=The Archaeology of Africa : food, metals and towns|year=1995|publisher=Routledge|location=London |isbn=041511585X|page=235|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TmUwjhQX-rcC&lpg=PA235&pg=PA235#v=onepage&q&f=false|edition=New |chapter=Rock art and pastoralism}}</ref> }} period (3550–3070 BCE), elephant images by the San bushmen in the South African [[Cederberg]] Wilderness Area suggest to researchers that they had "a symbolic association with elephants" and "had a deep understanding of the communication, behaviour and social structure of elephant family units" and "possibly developed a symbiotic relationship with elephants that goes back thousands of years."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Paterson |first=Andrew |title=Elephants (!X6 ) of the Cederberg Wilderness Area |journal=The Digging Stick |date=December 2004 |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=1–4 |url=http://www.archaeologysa.co.za/images/uploads/vol_24_no_3_1.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=12 December 2012 |issn=1013-7521 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115103347/http://www.archaeologysa.co.za/images/uploads/vol_24_no_3_1.pdf |archivedate=15 November 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===Ancient=== [[File:Mamallapuram rock carvings.jpg|thumb|''[[Descent of the Ganges (Mahabalipuram)|Descent of the Ganges]]'' [[rock relief]] at [[Mahabalipuram]], 7th-century]] Indian [[rock relief]]s include a number of depictions of elephants, notably the ''[[Descent of the Ganges (Mahabalipuram)|Descent of the Ganges]]'' at [[Mahabalipuram]], a large 7th-century Hindu scene with many figures that uses the form of the rock to shape the image.<ref>Harle, J.C., The Art and Architecture of the Indian Subcontinent, 2nd edn. 1994, Yale University Press Pelican History of Art, {{ISBN|0300062176}}, pp. 278-83</ref> At [[Unakoti]], [[Tripura]] there is an 11th-century group of reliefs related to [[Shiva]], including several elephants.
[[Indian painting]] includes many elephants, especially ones ridden for battle and royal transport in [[Mughal miniature]]s.
===Modern=== Elephants are often featured in modern artistic works, including those by artists such as [[Norman Rockwell]],<ref>{{cite web|title=''Two Boys on an Elephant'' by Norman Rockwell|url=http://www.best-norman-rockwell-art.com/norman-rockwell-country-gentleman-cover-1919-08-16-two-boys-on-an-elephant.html|publisher=Best Norman Rockwell Art.com.|accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref> [[Andy Warhol]]<ref name=Coskun>{{cite web|title=African Elephant, 1983 – Andy Warhol |url=http://www.coskunfineart.com/details.asp?workID=91 |work=The Endangered Species portfolio |publisher=Coskun Fine Art |accessdate=11 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016095653/http://www.coskunfineart.com/details.asp?workID=91 |archivedate=16 October 2014 |df= }}</ref> and [[Banksy]].<ref>Wyatt, Edward. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/16/arts/design/16bank.html?_r=0&adxnnl=1&adxnnlx=1355239900-9NfINmpLkugBXr9mK94T4w ''A Splashy Los Angeles Debut by Banksy'' – Design – New York Times], Published 16 September 2006. Retrieved 11 December 2012</ref> The stork-legged elephant, found in many of [[Salvador Dalí]]'s works,{{efn|For example, see:  ''[[Dream Caused by the Flight of a Bee Around a Pomegranate a Second Before Awakening]]'' and ''[[The Elephants]]''}} is one of the [[Surrealism|surrealist]]'s best known Icons, and adorn the walls of the [[Dalí Theatre and Museum|Dalí Museum in Spain]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Salvador Dali Gallery – ''Memories of Surrealism : Space Elephant'' |url=http://www.salvadordaliexperts.com/daligallery.html |publisher=SalvadorDaliExperts.com |accessdate=12 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407002737/http://www.salvadordaliexperts.com/daligallery.html |archivedate=7 April 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>In Kerala the elephant is a most popular motif in temple and church art, architecture, sculpture. See e.g.George Menachery, The Elephant and the Christians, (Malayalam) South Asia Research Assistance Services, 2014, forward by Madambu Kunjikkuttan)</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='Aanayum Nazraniyum'|url=http://www.indianchristianity.com/html/Pazhama-1-mailFINAL%20Oct14.pdf}}</ref>
==Politics and secular society== The elephant is also depicted by various political groups and in secular society.
===In Asia=== Asian cultures admire the high intelligence and good memory of Asian elephants. As such, they symbolise wisdom<ref>{{cite book|last=Guading|first=Madonna|title=The signs and symbols bible : the definitive guide to mysterious markings|year=2009|publisher=Sterling Pub. Co|location=New York|isbn=1402770049|pages=239|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SImTll3uupIC&lpg=PP1&hl=tl&pg=PA239#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and royal power. They are used as a representative of various political parties such as [[United National Party]] of [[Sri Lanka]] and [[Bahujan Samaj Party]] of India. The [[Elephants in Kerala culture|Elephants of Kerala]] are an integral part of the daily life in [[Kerala]], South India.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ObFCT5_taSgC&pg=PA312&dq=Elephants+Kerala+culture&as_brr=3|title=The Encyclopaedia of Indian Literature|volume=One (A To Devo)|publisher=}}</ref> These [[Indian elephant]]s are loved, revered, groomed and given a prestigious place in the state's culture.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G2yWe6ulHkEC&pg=PA4&dq=Elephants+Kerala+culture&as_brr=3|title=South India|publisher=}}</ref> There they are often referred to as the 'sons of the ''[[Sahyadri|sahya]]''.' The elephant is the state animal of Kerala and is featured on the emblem of the [[Government of Kerala]]. The elephant is also on the flag of the [[Kingdom of Laos]] with three elephants visible, supporting an umbrella (another symbol of royal power) until it became a republic in 1975. Other Southeast Asian realms have also displayed one or more white elephants.
The elephant also lends its name to some landmarks in Asia. [[Elephanta Island]] (also called "Gharapuri Island") in [[Mumbai Harbour]] was given this name by 17th century [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese]] explorers who saw a monolithic basalt sculpture of an elephant near the entrance to what became known as the [[Elephanta Caves]]. The Portuguese attempted to take it home with them but ended up dropping it into the sea because their chains were not strong enough. Later, the British moved this elephant to the Victoria and Albert Museum (now [[Dr. Bhau Daji Lad Museum]]) in [[Mumbai]].<ref>HT Cafe, Mumbai, Monday, 4 June 2007 p. 31; Article: "Lord of the Islands" by Jerry Pinto</ref>
===In Europe=== [[File:Keten Olifant.jpg|thumb|Collar of the Danish Order of the Elephant.]] {{See also|History of elephants in Europe}} Aside from being a curiosity for Europeans, the elephant also became a symbol of military might from the experience of fighting foreign powers that fielded [[war elephant]]s throughout history.<ref>{{cite book|last=Brosius|first=Maria|title=The Persians: an introduction|year=2006|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0415320895|pages=200|edition=1st }}</ref> After [[Alexander the Great]]'s victory over [[King Porus]] of India, the captured war elephants became a symbol of [[Imperialism|imperial power]], being used as an emblem of the [[Seleucid]] [[Diadoch]] empire. Later, when [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] wanted a monument to his own imperial power, he decreed that a colossal bronze [[Elephant of the Bastille|elephant fountain]] be cast from guns captured at his victorious [[Battle of Friedland]], for the site where the [[Bastille]] once stood.<ref name=Bingham>{{cite book|last1=Bingham|first1=Denis|title=The Bastille, Volume 2|date=1901|publisher=J. Pott|location=Princeton University|page=447|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cblCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA447#v=onepage&q&f=false|format=eBook}}</ref>
The [[Order of the Elephant]] ({{lang-da|Elefantordenen}}) is the highest [[Order (decoration)|order]] of Denmark. This very select religious organization was founded by [[Christian I of Denmark|King Christian I]] in 1478, using the elephant as a symbol of docility, sobriety and piety;<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lach|first1=Donald F.|title=Asia in the making of Europe.|date=1970|publisher=University of Chicago Press.|location=Chicago|isbn=0226467503|pages=132–133|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c0hcC3Jo2MMC&pg=PA132&lpg=PA133#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> instituted in its current form in 1693 by [[Christian V of Denmark|King Christian V]].
[[File:Castororpollux.jpg|thumb|One of the elephants shot for its [[Elephant meat|meat]] at Paris in December 1870.]] The killing and eating of the elephants [[Castor and Pollux (elephants)|Castor and Pollux]] from the [[Jardin des Plantes|Botanical gardens]] during the 1870 [[Siege of Paris (1870–1871)|Siege of Paris]] received considerable attention at the time. This became emblematic of the hardships and degradation caused by siege and war, especially since the two elephants were previously very popular with the Parisian public.
The city of [[Catania]], Sicily has an immemorial connection with the elephant. The local sorcerer [[Heliodorus of Catania|Heliodorus]], was credited with either riding a magic elephant or transforming himself into this animal. Under Medieval Arab rule Catania was known as ''Medinat-Al-Fil'' or ''Balad-Al-Fil'' (City/State of the Elephant). The symbol of the city is the ''Fontana dell'Elefante'' (Fountain of the Elephant) assembled in its present form in 1736 by [[Giovanni Battista Vaccarini]].
[[File:Elephant & Castle, London, England.jpg|thumb|left|Iconic statue at London's [[Elephant & Castle tube station]]]] In Central London, England, an area known as the "[[Elephant and Castle]]" (or "The Elephant") is centered on a major road intersection and a station of the [[London Underground]]. The "Castle" in the location's name refers to a medieval perception of a [[Howdah]]. The [[Heraldry|heraldic]] elephant and castle has also been associated with the city of [[Coventry]], England since medieval times, where it denotes religious symbolism{{efn|"The elephant is seen, not only as a beast so strong that he can carry a tower – Coventry's castle – full of armed men, but also as a symbol of Christ's redemption of the human race."<ref name="Coventry-CC">{{cite web|title=Coat of Arms : History of the Coat of Arms |url=http://www.coventry.gov.uk/info/1001/lord_mayor-general_information/888/coat_of_arms |publisher=Coventry City Council |accessdate=13 June 2014 |ref=CCC |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714225117/http://www.coventry.gov.uk/info/1001/lord_mayor-general_information/888/coat_of_arms |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }}</ref>}} and with the town of [[Dumbarton, Scotland]].{{efn|''cf'': [[:File:Civic Arms, Dumbarton.JPG| Dumbarton Civic Coat of Arms]] and [[:File:Dumbarton FC logo.svg|Dumbarton Football Club crest]]}} More recently in Britain, [[Welephant]], a red elephant cartoon character with a fireman's helmet, was originally used as a mascot by [[fire brigades in the United Kingdom]] to promote fire safety for children and has become the mascot for the Children's Burn Trust.<ref name=Welephant>{{cite web|title=The History of the National Fire Safety Charity for Children |url=http://www.welephant.co.uk/history2.htm |work=Welephant web site |publisher=National Fire Safety Charity for Children |accessdate=4 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728130553/http://www.welephant.co.uk/history2.htm |archivedate=28 July 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
{{clear left}} ===In America=== [[File:NastRepublicanElephant.jpg|thumb|1874 [[Thomas Nast]] cartoon featuring the first notable appearance of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]'s elephant.<ref>[http://www.harpweek.com/09Cartoon/BrowseByDateCartoon.asp?Year=2003&Month=November&Date=7 Cartoon of the Day: "The Third-Term Panic"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921045800/http://www.harpweek.com/09Cartoon/BrowseByDateCartoon.asp?Year=2003&Month=November&Date=7 |date=21 September 2011 }}. Retrieved on 2008-09-01</ref>]] The elephant as the symbol for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] of the United States originated in an 1874 political cartoon of an Asian elephant by [[Thomas Nast]] in ''[[Harper's Weekly]]''. This cartoon, titled "Third Term Panic", is a parody of [[Aesop's fable]],{{efn|Although the caption quotes the fable, Nast attributes it to —''[[Baconian theory of Shakespeare authorship|Shakespear or Bacon]]''}} "[[The Ass in the Lion's Skin]]". It depicts an elephant (labelled ''The Republican Vote'') running toward a ''chasm of chaos''; frightening a [[donkey|jackass]]{{efn|Contrary to popular belief, Nast did not originate the donkey (a derogatory reference to [[Andrew Jackson|Andrew "Jackass" [Jackson]]]) as the symbol of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]<ref>{{cite news|title=How the parties got their animal symbols|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/how-the-parties-got-their-animal-symbols/|work=(CBS News)|publisher=CBS Interactive Inc|accessdate=25 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Dewey|first=Donald|title=The art of ill will : the story of American political cartoons|year=2007|publisher=New York University Press|location=New York|isbn=0814719856|pages=14–18}}</ref>}} in a lion's skin (labelled ''[[Caesarism]]'') which scatters animals representing various interests. Although Nast used the elephant seven more times to represent the "Republican Vote", he did not use it to represent the ''Republican Party'' until March 1884 in "The Sacred Elephant".<ref>{{cite web|last=Kennedy |first=Robert C. |title=The Third-Term Panic |url=http://www.harpweek.com/09Cartoon/RelatedCartoon.asp?Month=November&Date=7 |work=Cartoon of the Day |publisher=HarpWeek |accessdate=25 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226094436/http://www.harpweek.com/09Cartoon/RelatedCartoon.asp?Month=November&Date=7 |archivedate=26 December 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===In Africa=== Many African cultures revere the African Elephant as a symbol of strength and power.<ref>{{cite web|title=383. African Elephant (Loxodonta africana)|url=http://www.edgeofexistence.org/mammals/species_info.php?id=77|publisher=EDGE: Mammal Species Information|accessdate=7 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=West African Elephants|url=http://www.cms.int/species/elephants/index.htm|publisher=Convention on Migratory Species|accessdate=7 December 2012}}</ref> It is also praised for its size, longevity, stamina, mental faculties, cooperative spirit, and loyalty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Elephant: The Animal and Its Ivory in African Culture |url=http://www.fowler.ucla.edu/category/exhibitions-education/elephant-animal-and-its-ivory-african-culture |publisher=Fowler Museum at UCLA |accessdate=24 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330072035/http://www.fowler.ucla.edu/category/exhibitions-education/elephant-animal-and-its-ivory-african-culture |archivedate=30 March 2013 |df= }}</ref> South Africa, uses elephant tusks in their [[Coat of arms of South Africa|coat of arms]] to represent wisdom, strength, moderation and eternity.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Coat of Arms |url=http://www.info.gov.za/aboutgovt/symbols/coa/index.htm |publisher=South African Government Information |accessdate=7 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904094036/http://www.info.gov.za/aboutgovt/symbols/coa/index.htm |archivedate=4 September 2012 |df= }}</ref> The elephant is symbolically important to the nation of [[Ivory Coast]] (''Côte d'Ivoire''); the [[Coat of arms of Ivory Coast]] features an elephant head [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] as its focal point.
In the western African [[Kingdom of Dahomey]] (now part of [[Benin]]) the elephant was associated with the 19th century rulers of the [[Fon people]], [[Guezo]] and his son [[Glele]].{{efn|Guezo and Glele ruled from 1818 to 1858 and from 1858 to 1889, respectively}} The animal is believed to evoke strength, royal legacy, and enduring memory as related by the proverbs: "''There where the elephant passes in the forest, one knows''" and "''The animal steps on the ground, but the elephant steps down with strength''."<ref>{{cite web|title=Elephant Figure {{!}} Fon peoples {{!}} The Met|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/318417|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref> Their flag depicted an elephant wearing a royal crown.
{{gallery |height= 125 |width= 180 |align= center |lines= 2 | File:Coat of arms of Ivory Coast.svg |[[Ivory Coast]] coat of arms, (ca 1964–2000) | File:Flag of Siam (1855).svg|[[Flag of Thailand|Flag of Siam]] (Thailand), (1855–1916) | File:Flag of Laos (1952-1975).svg|Flag of the [[Kingdom of Laos]], (1952–1975) | File:Dahomey kingdom flag.png|Flag of the [[Kingdom of Dahomey]], (ca 1888) }}
==Popular culture==
<!-- Before adding references to recent mentions of this article in the media, please see the talk page.
Thank you. --> The elephant has entered into popular culture through various [[idiom]]atic expressions and [[adage]]s.
The phrase "Elephants never forget" refers to the belief that elephants have excellent memories. The variation "Women and elephants never forget an injury" originates from the 1904 book ''Reginald on Besetting Sins'' by British writer Hector Hugh Munro, better known as [[Saki]].<ref>{{wikiquotelang|en|Saki#Reginald (1904)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Jenkins | date=1 June 2001 | title=Why Elephants Never Forget | first=Dr. Orville Boyd | url=http://orvillejenkins.com/words/elephant.html | accessdate=7 December 2011}}</ref>
This adage seems to have a basis in fact, as reported in ''[[Scientific American]]'':
::Remarkable [[Explicit memory|recall power]], researchers believe, is a big part of how elephants survive. Matriarch elephants, in particular, hold a store of social knowledge that their families can scarcely do without, according to research conducted on elephants at [[Amboseli National Park]] in Kenya.<ref name="Sci-Am">{{cite web|last=Ritchie|first=James|title=Fact or Fiction?: Elephants Never Forget|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=elephants-never-forget|publisher=Scientific American|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref> "[[Seeing the Elephant]]" is a 19th-century Americanism denoting a world-weary experience;<ref name="Wilton(2006)">{{cite web|last1=Wilton|first1=Dave|date=13 June 2006|title=elephant, to see the|url=http://www.wordorigins.org/index.php/site/comments/elephant_to_see_the/|website=Wordorigins.org|accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref> often used by soldiers, pioneers and adventurers to qualify new and exciting adventures such as the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], the [[Oregon Trail]] and the [[California Gold Rush]].<ref name="Wilton(2006)"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Seeing the Elephant|url=http://www.nha.org/history/hn/HNelephant.htm|website=Historic Nantucket|publisher=Nantucket Historical Association|accessdate=30 July 2014|quote=Originally published in the ''Historic Nantucket'', Vol 48, no. 3 (Summer 1999), p. 28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SEEING THE ELEPHANT|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1861/03/01/news/seeing-the-elephant.html|website=New York Times|accessdate=30 July 2014|date=1 March 1861}}</ref> A "[[white elephant]]" has become a term referring to an expensive burden, particularly when much has been invested with false expectations. The term 'white elephant sale' was sometimes used in Australia as a synonym for [[jumble sale]]. In the U.S., a [[White elephant gift exchange]] is a popular winter holiday party activity. The idiom [[Elephant in the room]] tells of an obvious truth that no one wants to discuss, alluding to the animal's size compared to a small space. "[[Seeing pink elephants]]" refers to a drunken hallucination and is the basis for the [[Pink Elephants on Parade]] sequence in the 1941 [[Disney animated feature]], ''[[Dumbo]]''. "Jumbo" has entered the English language as a synonym for "large".{{efn|As a product size, by 1886 (cigars); ''Jumbo jet'' attested by 1964.<ref name="Jumbo"/>}} [[Jumbo]] originally was the name of a huge elephant acquired by circus showman [[P. T. Barnum]] from the [[London Zoo]] in 1882. The name itself may have come from a West African{{efn|Kongo: ''Nzamba''<ref name="Jumbo"/>}} native word for "elephant".<ref name="Jumbo">{{cite web|last=Harper|first=Douglas|title=jumbo|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=jumbo|publisher=Online Etymology Dictionary|accessdate=13 December 2012}}</ref>
===Literature=== [[File:'The Steam House' by Léon Benett 018.jpg|thumbnail|[[Léon Benett]]'s illustration of [[Jules Verne]]'s mechanical elephant from ''[[The Steam House]]'' (1880)]] The elephant is viewed in both positive and negative lights in similar fashion as humans in various forms of literature. In fact, [[Pliny the Elder]] praised the beast in his ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Naturalis Historia]]'' as one that is closest to a human in sensibilities.<ref>{{cite book|title=Renaissance Beasts: Of Animals, Humans, and Other Wonderful Creatures|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=9780252091339|pages=172–173|editor=Erica Fudge|year=2004}}</ref> The elephant's different connotations clash in [[Ivo Andrić]]'s novella ''The Vizier's Elephant''. Here the citizens of [[Travnik]] despise the young elephant who symbolises the cruelty of the unseen [[Vizier]]. However, the elephant itself is young and innocent despite unknowingly causing havoc due to youthful play.<ref>{{cite web|title=Priča o vezirovom slonu/The Story of the Vizier's Elephant|url=http://www.ivoandric.org.rs/html/the_story_of_the_vizier_s_elep.html|publisher=The Ivo Andrić Foundation|accessdate=7 December 2012}}</ref> In the [[Tarzan]] novels of [[Edgar Rice Burroughs]], ''[[Tantor]]'' is the generic term for "elephant" in the fictional [[simian]] ''[[Mangani]]'' language, but is associated with a particular elephant who eventually becomes Tarzan's faithful companion. Other elephant characters that are shown in a positive light include [[Jean de Brunhoff]]'s [[Babar the Elephant|Babar]] and [[Dr. Seuss]]' [[Horton the Elephant|Horton]]. [[Jules Verne]] featured a steam-powered mechanical elephant in his 1880 novel ''[[The Steam House]]''. In addition, the animal is depicted in its military use through the [[oliphaunt]]s of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' trilogy and the alien invaders of [[Larry Niven]] and [[Jerry Pournelle]]'s 1985 science fiction novel, ''[[Footfall]]''.
Notable short stories featuring elephants include [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s "[[Toomai of the Elephants]]" and "[[The Elephant's Child]]"; as well as [[Mark Twain]]'s "[[The Stolen White Elephant]]". [[George Orwell]] wrote an [[Allegory|allegorical]] [[essay]], "[[Shooting an Elephant]]"; and in "[[Hills Like White Elephants]]", [[Ernest Hemingway]] used the allegorical white elephant, alluding to a pregnancy as an unwanted gift.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Johnston|first1=Kenneth G.|title=Hills Like White Elephants|journal=Studies in American Fiction|date=Autumn 1982|volume=10|issue=2|pages=230–238}}</ref>
The animal is also seen in historical novels. ''[[The Elephant's Journey]]'' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]: ''A Viagem do Elefante'', 2008) is a novel by [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel laureate]]<ref>{{cite web|title=1998 : José Saramago|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1998/index.html|work=The Nobel Prize in Literature|publisher=Nobelprize.org|accessdate=17 December 2012}}</ref> [[José Saramago]]. This is a fictional account based on an historical 16th century journey from [[Lisbon, Portugal|Lisbon]] to [[Vienna, Austria|Vienna]] by an [[Suleiman (elephant)|elephant named Solomon]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Le Guin|first=Ursula K|title=The Elephant's Journey by José Saramago|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/jul/24/elephants-journey-jose-saramago-review|work=Book of the week|publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|accessdate=17 December 2012|location=London|date=24 July 2010}}</ref> ''[[An Elephant for Aristotle]]'' is a 1958 historical novel by [[L. Sprague de Camp]]. It concerns the adventures of a [[Thessalian]] [[cavalry]] commander who has been tasked by [[Alexander the Great]] to bring an elephant captured from [[King Porus]] of India, to [[Athens]] as a present for Alexander's old tutor, [[Aristotle]].
Elephants can also represent the hugeness and wildness of the imagination, as in [[Ursula Dubosarsky]]<!-- and Andrew Joyner-->'s 2012 children's book, ''Too Many Elephants in This House'',<ref>{{cite book|last=Joyner|first=Ursula Dubosarsky ; illustrated by Andrew|title=Too many elephants in this house|year=2012|publisher=Penguin Books Australia|location=Camberwell, Vic.|isbn=0670075469|pages=32|url=https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN9780670075461}}</ref> which also plays with the notion of the [[elephant in the room]].<ref>Review by Robin Morrow "Too Many Elephants in This House" Magpies Vol.27 2012 p.8</ref> An imaginary elephant can (perhaps) become real, as with the elusive [[Heffalump]]. Although never specified as an elephant in [[A. A. Milne]]'s [[Winnie the Pooh]] stories, a heffalump physically resembles an elephant; and [[E. H. Shepard]]'s illustration shows an Indian elephant. "''Heffalump''" has since been defined as "a child's term for an elephant."<ref>{{cite dictionary | year = 2014 | title = Definition of ''heffalump'' in English | dictionary = Oxford Dictionary | volume = British & World English | edition = Online | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = | id = | url = http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/us/definition/english/heffalump }}</ref>
===Sports=== The elephant is used as a mascot or logo for various sports groups.
Circus showman [[P. T. Barnum]] donated the stuffed hide of [[Jumbo]] the elephant to [[Tufts University]]'s in 1885, where Jumbo soon became the mascot for their sports teams. However, all that remains of Jumbo are some ashes stored in a peanut butter jar and a piece of his tail following a fire in 1975. "Jumbo's spirit lives on" in the peanut butter jar which is ceremoniously passed on to successive Athletic Directors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jumbo the Elephant, Tufts' Mascot|url=http://www.tufts.edu/home/get_to_know_tufts/history/jumbo/|website=Get to Know Tufts|publisher=Tufts University|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref>
The mascot for the [[Oakland Athletics]] (A's) baseball team is based on the figurative white elephant. The story of picking the mascot began when [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]]' manager [[John McGraw (baseball)|John McGraw]] told reporters that Philadelphia manufacturer [[Benjamin Shibe]], who owned the controlling interest in the new team, had a "white elephant on his hands"; manager [[Connie Mack]] defiantly adopted the white elephant as the team mascot.{{efn|Over the years, the A's elephant mascot has appeared in various colours other than white, and was briefly replaced by a mule}} The A's are sometimes, but infrequently, referred to as the 'Elephants' or 'White Elephants'. Their mascot is nicknamed [[Stomper]].
[[University of Alabama]]'s [[Alabama Crimson Tide|Crimson Tide]] mascot has been an elephant since 1930 after a sportswriter wrote of a fan yelling "Hold your horses, the elephants are coming!" as the football team rumbled onto the field.<ref>{{cite web|title=Big Al|url=http://www.rolltide.com/sports/c-cheer/spec-rel/big-al.html|work=Crimson Tide|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=10 May 2014}}</ref> Their elephant-costumed "[[Big Al (mascot)|Big Al]]" officially debuted at the [[1979 Sugar Bowl]].
[[Catania, Italy]] uses the elephant to represent [[Catania Elephants|their football team]], referencing the animal that has represented their city since ancient times.
===Music=== The elephant is also represented in music such as [[Henry Mancini]]'s hit song "[[Baby Elephant Walk]]", which has been described as "musical shorthand for kookiness of any stripe".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mills|first1=Ted|title=Henry Mancini : ''Hatari!'' : Review|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/hatari!-mw0000200845|website=AllMusic|publisher=All Media Network}}</ref> The American band [[the White Stripes]]' fourth album was entitled ''[[Elephant (album)|Elephant]] ''in honour of the animal's brute strength and closeness to its relatives.<ref>{{cite web|last=DiCrescenzo|first=Brent|title=The White Stripes: Elephant|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/8652-elephant/|publisher=Pitchfork|accessdate=8 February 2013|date=1 April 2003|quote=The album title refers to the endangered animal's brute power and less honored instinctual memory for dead relatives}}</ref> The hit single "[[Elephant (Alexandra Burke song)|Elephant]]" by British recording artist [[Alexandra Burke]] is based on the expression "[[elephant in the room]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Love|first=Ryan|title=Alexandra Burke interview: 'Elephant is just the beginning'|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/interviews/a359339/alexandra-burke-interview-elephant-is-just-the-beginning.html|work=Digital Spy|publisher=Hearst Magazines UK|accessdate=24 January 2013|date=10 January 2012}}</ref> "[[Nellie the Elephant]]" is a children's song first released in 1956 and since covered by many artists including the punk-rock band [[Toy Dolls]];<ref name=NIEHS>{{cite web|title=Nellie the Elephant (lyrics only) |url=http://kids.niehs.nih.gov/games/songs/childrens/nellie.htm |work=NIEHS Kids Pages |publisher=National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences |accessdate=23 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130228061858/http://kids.niehs.nih.gov/games/songs/childrens/nellie.htm |archivedate=28 February 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===Film and television=== The elephant is also featured in film and on television. Thailand has produced various movies about the animal, from the 1940 historical drama film ''[[King of the White Elephant]]'' to the 2005 martial-arts action film, ''[[Tom-Yum-Goong]]''.{{efn|US title: ''The Protector'', UK title: ''Warrior King''}} In the West, the elephant was popularised by ''[[Dumbo]]'', the elephant who learns to fly in the 1941 [[Disney animated feature]] of the same name. Kipling's "[[Toomai of the Elephants]]" was adapted as the 1937 British adventure film ''[[Elephant Boy (film)|Elephant Boy]]''. In popular modern films, [[Tai (elephant)|Tai the elephant-actress]] has portrayed Bo Tat in ''[[Operation Dumbo Drop]]'' (1995), Vera in ''[[Larger than Life (film)|Larger than Life]]'' (1996) and Rosie in ''[[Water for Elephants (film)|Water for Elephants]]'' (2011).
On television, ''[[Nellie the Elephant (TV series)|Nellie the Elephant]]'' is a 1990 UK cartoon series inspired by the song of the same name, featuring Scottish singer [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]] voicing Nelly. [[Britt Allcroft]] adapted "Mumfie" the elephant from Katherine Tozer's series of children's books,{{efn|The first book ''Mumfie Marches On'', published during World War II (1942) was suggested by the British government; which culminates in the capture of Adolph Hitler by Mumfie and allies<ref>{{cite book|last1=Edwards|first1=Owen Dudley|title=British children's fiction in the Second World War|date=2003|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=Edinburgh|isbn=0748616519|pages=318, 350|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C8h87i1OaEgC}}</ref>}} originally in a '70s televised [[puppet show]] and then in the '90s animated ''[[Magic Adventures of Mumfie]]'' series.
===Games=== The elephant can also be found in games. In [[shatranj]], the medieval game from which [[chess]] developed, the piece corresponding to the modern [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]] was known as [[Alfil (chess)|''Pil'' or ''Alfil'']] ("Elephant"; from Persian and Arabic,{{efn|From Persian پيل pīl; al- is the Arabic for "the"}} respectively).<ref>{{cite book|last=Golombek|first=Harry|title=Chess : a history|year=1976|publisher=Putnam|location=New York|isbn=0399115757|url=}}</ref> In the Indian [[chaturanga]] game the piece is also called "Elephant" (''Gaja''). The same is true in [[Chinese chess]],{{efn|''Xiangqi'' ([[Chinese language|Chinese]]: {{lang|zh|{{linktext|象棋}}}}, <small>[[pinyin|p]]</small> ''Xiàngqí''), sometimes translated as "the elephant game".<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Play Chinese Chess : Xiangqi|url=http://ancientchess.com/page/play-xiangqi.htm|publisher=AncientChess.com|accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> }} which has an elephant piece ("Xiàng", 象) that serves as a defensive piece, being the only one that may not cross the river dividing the game board. In the Japanese [[shogi]] version, the piece was known as the "''Drunken'' Elephant"; however, it was dropped by order of the [[Emperor Go-Nara]] and no longer appears in the version played in contemporary Japan. Even with modern Chess, the word for the [[Bishop (chess)|bishop]] is still ''Alfil'' in Spanish, ''Alfiere'' in Italian, ''Feel'' in Persian, and "Elephant" (Слон) in Russian. All of these games originally simulated a kind of battlefield, thus this piece represented a [[war elephant]]. In the present-day canonical [[Staunton chess set]], the piece's deep groove, which originally represented the elephant's tusks, is now regarded as representing a bishop's (or abbot's) [[mitre]]. The Asian subspecie was included in [[Far Cry 4]]'s handbook, comparing the animal to Pagan Min's nobility and humility.
==Architecture== In the 18th-century, French architect [[Charles Ribart]] planned to build a three-level elephant building at the Paris site where the [[Arc de Triomphe]] was eventually built. Nothing became of this, but in the early 19th-century, [[Napoleon]] conceived of an even larger elephant structure, the [[Elephant of the Bastille]]. Although the ambitious project was never completed with its intended bronze elephant, a full-sized plaster and wood-frame model stood in its place. After Napoleon's defeat, this structure eventually became a neglected eyesore, and a setting in [[Victor Hugo]]'s 1862 novel, ''[[Les Misérables]]''.
Three multi-story elephant shaped buildings were built in America by [[James V. Lafferty]] in the 1880s. The largest, seven-story, thirty-one room [[Elephantine Colossus]] served as a hotel, concert hall, and attraction on [[Coney Island]] before it burned down in 1896. The six-story [[Lucy the Elephant]] is the only remaining of the three, and survives as a tourist attraction near [[Atlantic City]]. These giant elephant structures, however, are dwarfed by the 32-story [[Bangkok]] [[Elephant Tower]] in Thailand. This iconic elephant-inspired building reflects the influence of the elephant in Thai culture.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chang (Elephant) Building|url=http://www.bkkkids.com/activities/chang-elephant-building/|publisher=BKK Kids|accessdate=10 March 2014|date=9 October 2013}}</ref>
==Gallery== [[File:Elephant catching a flying tengu.jpg|178px|thumbnail|right|{{nowrap|Elephant catching a flying [[tengu]]}}]] <!--BEGIN: gallery (landscape, large)--> {{gallery |height= 190 |width= 268 |align= center |lines= 3 | File:Blind monks examining an elephant.jpg|Buddhist parable of the blind monks examining an elephant; illustrated by [[Hanabusa Itchō|Itchō Hanabusa]]. (1888 [[Ukiyo-e]] [[Woodblock printing|woodcut]]) |File:RoyalWhiteElephant.jpg|A royal white elephant in 19th century Thai art }}<!--END: (landscape, large)-->
<!-- BEGIN: gallery (portrait, medium) --> {{gallery | height= 164 |width= 122 |align= center |lines= 4 | File:Catane Fontana Dell elefante.jpg|''Fontana dell'Elefante'' (Fountain of the Elephant); [[Catania, Italy|Catania]]'s symbol | File:Udaygiri2.jpg|Elephant statues at the [[Buddhist]] [[Udayagiri and Khandagiri Caves|Udaygiri temple ruins]] in [[Odisha]], India | File:Norman Rockwell Cover-August 16, 1919.jpg|''Country Gentleman'' magazine. [[Norman Rockwell]] cover, 16 August 1919 | File:Elephant african mask.jpg|African elephant mask ([[Ivory Coast]]) | File:Brooklyn Museum 81.170 Kuosi Society Elephant Mask.jpg|Kuosi Society ([[Bamileke people]]) Elephant Mask, [[Brooklyn Museum]] }}<!--END: portrait, medium-->
<!--BEGIN gallery (landscape, small)--> {{gallery |height= 110 |width= 140 |align= center |lines= 5 | File:Hannibal in Italy by Jacopo Ripanda - Sala di Annibale - Palazzo dei Conservatori - Musei Capitolini - Rome 2016 (2).jpg|''Hannibal Crossing the Alps''; detail of fresco by [[Jacopo Ripanda]], ca. 1510, [[Capitoline Museums]], [[Rome, Italy|Rome]] | File:Thrippunithura-Elephant-end-of-pooram-2 crop.jpg|[[Caparison]]ed elephants at ''[[Sree Poornathrayesa temple]]'' festival [[Thrippunithura]] in Kerala, [[south India]]. | File:Erawan.JPG|[[Erawan]] statue in [[Chiang Mai]], Thailand | File:Elephant de la Bastille aquarelle de Jean Alavoine 2.jpg| ''Dernier projet pour la fontaine de l'Éléphant de la Bastille'' (1809–1810), Watercolor by [[Jean-Antoine Alavoine]] | File:Syrischer Maler von 1354 001.jpg|1354 illustration depicting [[Panchatantra]] fable: ''Rabbit fools Elephant by showing the reflection of the moon'' }}<!--END gallery-->
==See also== {{colbegin}} * [[Aung Pinle Hsinbyushin]], Lord of the White Elephant of Aung Pinle, a [[Nat (spirit)|Great Nat]] of Burma. * [[Bholu (mascot)]], iconic mascot for Indian Railways * [[Elephants in ancient China]] * [[Elephants in Kerala culture]] * [[Elephants in Thailand]] * [[Elephant joke|Elephant riddle]] * [[Elephant test]] * [[Elephant clock]] * [[Elephant Parade]], sculpture exhibit * [[Execution by elephant]] * [[Fear of mice#Elephants and mice|Elephants and mice]] sub-section of [[Fear of mice]] article * ''[[Faithful Elephants]]'', story of the elephants in Tokyo's Ueno Zoo during World War II * [[Gaja]], elephants in ancient Hindu mythology * [[Hastin]], elephants in Vedic texts. * [[Jumbo (musical)|''Jumbo'', 1935 musical]] and [[Billy Rose's Jumbo (film)|1962 Film]] * [[Temple elephant]] * [[The Sultan's Elephant]], traveling show featuring a huge mechanical elephant * [[War elephant]] * [[List of fictional elephants]] * [[List of historical elephants]] * [[:Category: Metaphors referring to elephants]] {{colend}}
==Notes== {{notelist}}
== References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book|last=Scigliano|first=Eric|title=Love, war, and circuses : the age-old relationship between elephants and humans|year=2002|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|location=Boston|isbn=0618015833}} * {{cite book|last=Binney|first=Ruth|title=Nature's Ways Lore, Legend, Fact and Fiction.|year=2006|publisher=F+W Media|location=Newton Abbot|isbn=0715333933}} * {{cite journal|title=The Absurd Elephant: A Recent Riddle Fad|author=Ed Cray and Marilyn Eisenberg Herzog|journal=Western Folklore|volume=26|issue=1|date=January 1967|pages=27–36|doi=10.2307/1498485|publisher=Western Folklore, Vol. 26, No. 1|jstor=1498485}}—the evolution of the Elephant Riddle that entered U.S. folklore in California in 1963 * Druce, George C. [http://bestiary.ca/etexts/druce1919-2/druce%20-%20elephant%20in%20medieval%20legend%20and%20art.pdf "The Elephant in Medieval Legend and Art"]. ''Journal of the Royal Archaeological Institute''. (Vol. 76) London, 1919 * {{cite book|last=Robbins|first=Louise E.|title=Elephant slaves and pampered parrots : exotic animals in eighteenth century Paris|year=2002|publisher=Johns Hopkins Univ. Press|location=Baltimore [u.a.]|isbn=0801867533|edition=[Online-Ausg.]}} * {{cite book|last=Bedini|first=Silvio A.|authorlink=Silvio Bedini|title=The pope's elephant|year=1998|publisher=Sanders|location=Nashville|isbn=1879941414|edition=1. US}} * {{cite book|last=ed|first=Fowler Museum of Cultural History. Doran H. Ross,|title=Elephant : the animal and its ivory in African culture|year=1992|publisher=University of California|location=Los Angeles|isbn=0930741269}} *{{cite book|last= Mayor|first=Adrienne|authorlink=Adrienne Mayor|title=The First Fossil Hunters Dinosaurs, Mammoths, and Myth in Greek and Roman Times (New in Paper ; with a new introduction by the author).|year=2000|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton|isbn=1400838444|pages=54–103|chapter=CHAPTER 2. Earthquakes and Elephants: Prehistoric Remains in Mediterranean Lands|quote=[https://books.google.com/books?id=9TwhfvU08UcC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA54#v=onepage&q&f=false Limited preview on Google Books]}} *{{cite web|author1=''African Folktale as told by Humphrey Harman''|title=Thunder, Elephant, and Dorobo|url=https://www.greatbooks.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/ThunderElephant_OER_FINAL.pdf|website=greatbooks.org|publisher=[[Great Books Foundation]]|format=PDF}}
